On the 21st of May, I was in the Eight Bells there—I had been in the house but two or three minutes—I went in between two and three o'clock in the morning—a man challenged me to fight—he broke the glass I had with some bran day and water in it—there was no place to sit down—I took off my coat and lost it, but I do not know who took it—I put it on the counter of the bar—we did not fight—the man ran away, and I ran after him—it was not the prisoner but another man that wanted to fight me—I missed the coat before he ran away, and I suspected he was connected with the parties who were there—there were seven or eight persons standing together when I went in—they appeared to be conversing about different subjects.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How many persons were there altogether? A. About six or eight—I was passing from the fair with a friend—I was with the superintendent of the police and the high-constable, but they were not there then—I went in with a Mr. Tuck—he is not here—I had not been into any other public-house the whole day—I was engaged in my business till half-past ten o'clock—I had been at Mr. Tuck's, and drank six pennyworth of warm brandy and water—I do not say the pri
soner was at the public-house—I never saw him till he was in custody—he might have been behind me.

JOHN MARTIN MEWS . I am a pensioner in the Royal Hospital, and I sell coffee in the street. At a quarter past three o'clock, on the 26th of May, I was selling coffee about three yards from the door of the Bells—I saw the prisoner come out with a coat under his right arm—he went about two yards—there was no body with him—he took and shook it, and folded it up, and clapped it under his left arm—he went round by the church—it was quite light, I could see the dial—he is the man.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you sure you saw the dial? A. Yes—there are four to the church—it was a quarter after three o'clock—I had drank nothing but coffee—I arrived there at ten o'clock at night—I had had nothing but a glass of peppermint—I had been to no public-house that morning.

JOHN SIZER . (police-constable R 103.) On Thursday morning, at twenty minutes past three o'clock, Mr. Fagan told me he had lost his coat, and Mews told me something—I went after the prisoner, and found him near Greenwich church about twenty minutes past three—I asked if he had got a coat belonging to any one besides himself—he said, no, he had not—I did not search him—I asked him a second time, and he again denied it—I then said I should take him into custody, on suspicion of hav
ing stolen one—after we had walked four or five paces, he said he had a coat in the boot of his coach—we turned back again towards the coach, and he pulled this coat out from the boot of an omnibus coach, and gave it to me—this is it—I do not know whether he was the driver of it.
Cross-examined Q. Did he appear sober? A. He might have had some drink, but I did not see any effects of liquor.
Prisoner's Defence I picked the coat up on the step of the door.

EDWARD SMITH . I know the prisoner—he is foreman of Mr. Wolfe's omnibuses—I was with him that morning, and we had a pint of half-and-half together—I saw a fight with the prosecutor and another person—the prisoner left the house first, and I followed him—there were about ten person in front of the bar—when the prisoner got out I saw him shake this coat—he said, "I have got a coat of Somebody's—I picked it up on the threshold of the landlord's door"—it was all over dust—it had been trodden on in the room—he said, "I am going to put it into the boot of the omnibus, and when the owner comes he shall have it."

ALFRED WOLFE . I am the prisoner master. I was standing minding the omnibuses, and I saw the witness, Mews, at this time—I believe him to be drunk—the prisoner told me he had a cost placed in the boot of the omnibus.
NOT GUILTY .

1618.
JOHN ADAMS and
WILLIAM REDRUP were indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of May, 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
James Taverner, from his person.
JAMES TAVERNER . I live at Chelmsford. On Sunday, the 25th of
May, I was at Greenwich fair, and missed my handkerchief from my pocket, in the fair—it was produced by the officer—this is it.

JAMES ANDREWS (police constable M 45) I was on duty there, on the 25th of May—I saw the prisoners, and watched them a quarter of an hour, in company with a third person—I saw them attempt several persons' pocket, at last they came to the prosecutor, and Redrup took from his pocket this handkerchief, and gave it to Adams, who threw it down—I seized them both and took them to the station-house—I found on Redrup, a snuff-box and a pair of scissors.
(Adams received a good character.)

ADAMS—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

REDRUP—
GUILTY . Aged 19
Confined Six Months.

p.hi: Sixth Jury before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1619.
CHARLES COOPER was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of May, 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of
George Means, from his person.

GEORGE MEANS . I am a tailor, and live at Ann's-place, Hoxton. On the 23rd of May, I was at Greenwich fair, between the hours of three and four o'clock in the afternoon—Wild, the officer, tapped me on the shoulder and told me something—I immediately turned round, and at two or three yards distance, I saw the handkerchief lying on the ground—Wild picked it up, and collared the prisoner, and Dyke (another office) collared another person, and they were taken to the station-house—this is my handkerchief,

JAMES WILD (police-constable R 141.) I was on duty on the 23rd of May, at Greenwich fair—I saw the prosecutor there, and the prisoner and another young man were attempting several gentleman's pockets, going up and down the fair—another was with them, smoking a pipe—I then saw the prisoner and the other two men go behind the prosecutor—the prisoner took the handkerchief from the prosecutor's pocket, and put it into his trowsers pocket—he then pushed away from the prosecutor, and turned back to the fair—I torched the prosecutor, and told him—I then laid hold of the prisoner—he took and threw the handkerchief behind on the ground—I picket it up myself and took him.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you understand your duty in a place of this kind? A. Yes, it is to prevent crime—we did not take them till we satisfied ourselves what they were about—I saw them attempt several pockets—we have had an order before, from the superinten
dent's office. at Greenwhich, not to take attempts—I cannot give you any name, but I know I have received that order—the order was given at the office three or four years ago—Grant is the name of the other boy who attempted to pick pockets—the bills been ignored against him, and the third boy also.

WILLIAM DYKE (police-constable R 193.) I was in company with Wild—I saw the prisoner at the fair, and two more—I saw Cooper take the handkerchief from the prosecutor's pocket—I saw it come from the pocket—Wild was before me—he took him into custody—Wild caught hold of Copper directly—I saw the handkerchief on the ground—I took Grant and the other prisoner.

Cross-examined Q. How near you to the prisoner? A. Not more than one yard—Wild and the other two were between me and the prisoner—I saw the handkerchief in his hand—Wild immediately caught hold of him—I did not see him throw it on the ground—he might

have dropped the handkerchief directly—I did not see him put it into any pocket, or attempt to do so—I was in plain clothes, and so was Wild—I was not called the Grand Jury, although I was with him—no one but the prosecutor and Wild were called in.
COURT. Q. You saw the handkerchief in the prisoner's hand? A. I did—I then immediately took the other two—my attention was called off to them and I did not see the handkerchief on the ground.

Prisoner. We had not been ten minutes at the fair—we had only time to go into one show, and come out—we landed from the water, at there o'clock—I had a pint of beer, and then we got to the fair, and were locked up at half-past three o'clock.
NOT GUILTY .

1620.
GEORGE PERRIN was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of May, 1 shawl, value 5s., the goods of
Frances Clifton. The prosecutrix did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

1621.
NEAL BUSBY was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of May, 1 hand
kerchief, value 1s., and 4d., in money the goods monies of
Elizabeth Treadway, from her person.
The prosecutrix did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

1622.
EDRICK BEACHER and
WILLIAM LAWRENCE were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of May, 1 handkerchief value 1s., 6d., the goods of
Samuel Maynard, from his person.

WILLIAM DYKE (police-constable R 193) I was in Deptford fair with James Wild, on the 30th of May—I saw the prisoner Beacher, go behind the prosecutor with the other prisoner, and take the handkerchief from the prosecutor pocket, and then push into the crowed—Lawrence was close to him when he took the handkerchief, and it was passed in some way from Beacher to Lawrence, and was found on him; but I did not see it found, as he fell on the ground and kicked very much.

JAMES WILD (police-constable R 141.) I was with Dyke at Deptford fair between eleven and twelve o'clock at night—I saw both the prisoners standing behind the prosecutor—I saw Beacher pass something to Law
rence—I took Lawrence, and found this handkerchief in the flap of his trowsers—he threw himself down, and began to kick and bite very mach.
SAMUEL MAYNARD . I live at Layton-stone-hill, and am a waiter. I was in the fair looking at a show—this handkerchief if mine.

Beacher I was selling something in the fair, and saw a piece of work—I went up, and was taken—I did not have the handkerchief at all. Lawrence. He told the Magistrate he did not see the handkerchief come from the man's pocket—I picked it up, and did not steal it—nobody owned it, and I kept it myself.
WILLIAM DYKE . No, I told the Magistrate he was the person who received it, but the other too it—they were standing close to me and they were seized directly—the fair was very thin at that time.
JURY. Q. You said they pushed into the crowd? A. Yes, but the fair was getting thin—there were perhaps one hundred persons before them, but none behind.

BEACHER—
GUILTY . Aged 14.

LAWRENCE—
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years.

div0.p:
JAMES BROWN,
JAMES HAWKINS, and
JOSEPH SWINFORD , were attainted of burglary—See Page 257.

div1.p:
1623.
GEORGE SPARKS was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of April, 1 sack, and 1 1/2 bushel of oats, value 2s. 6d., the god of
Charles Reynolds his master.
MR. BODKIN declined offering any evidence.

1624.
GEORGE STAPLES was indicted
for perjury.

1625.
EDWARD BURN was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of May, 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the of
Thomas Fauntleroy, from his person.

THOMAS FAUNTLEROY . I live at Potter's-fields, and am ivory-mer
chant. On Tuesday, the 13th of May, I was in Tooley-street, and felt a tug at my coat pocket—I turned round suddenly and caught the prisoner's hand enclosing my handkerchief—I took it from him—I caught his hand and the handkerchief and the tail of my coat together—the handkerchief was all outside the pocket—it was gone from person, because my coat pocket dropped, and I took the handkerchief his hand.

Prisoner. I told you a boy that went along took it—you know well it was not me took the handkerchief—I told you it was another boy—you would not go after him Witness. He told me it was put into his hand by another boy—he was close behind me.
SAMUEL JAMES HALEY . I took charge of the prisoner, and have the handkerchief.

Prisoner. Q. Have you ever known me to dishonest in your life? Witness. I have known him the last six or seven years residing on the spot—I never knew any thing against him—it is some length of time since I knew him to be in any service—he was then a pot-boy.
Prisoner's Defence. I am innocent—I was going for some soap for my mother at the same time.
GUILTY . Aged 14—Recommended to mercy by the prosecutor.

Confined One Month, and
Whipped.

1626.
THOMAS WARD and
JOSEPH STONE were indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of May, 3 skewers, 20s., of
Jean Baptiste Alary, from his person.

JEAN BAPTISTE ALARY . I am a cook, and live in Park-street, Grosve
nor-square. On Saturday, the 21st of May, I was, I was on my return from Fetcham-park in a wagon—it was half-past ten o'clock when I arrived at Epson—it was about one o'clock in the morning when I lost my skewers—I cannot tell where I was, or in what part of the road—there were many person in the carriage—they stopped at a public-house—I got into a wagon—the prisoners were, there, but not when I left Epsom, they came in

afterwards—I found myself pushed about by them—I meant to walk on foot—I had my portmanteau, when I arrived at Epson—I could not get any coach—I saw one cart, and in that cart five or six gentlemen—they said, "You go to London?"—I said, "Yes, what time do you think you will take to arrive?"—they said, "Five or six hours"—I said, "How much you charge?"—he said, "1s. 6d."—they said, "Where is your port
manteau?"—I gave it to him—I got in and took my seat—they stopped a quarter of an hour at one public-house—it was about midnight—the cart stopped again—all the people got down except me—they said, "Come with me"—I said, "No, thank you"—they go in the public-house, and then they come in again in three quarters of an hour—that two prisoners came by my side—I was sleepy—in half an hour I felt my pocket touched—I thought these men would have something from my pocket—a few minutes after I felt the skewers gone from my pocket—after that these men touched my pocket again, and said, "You can sing an Italian song?"—these two left, and the man changed his seat, and squeezed me as much as possible—after that I slept a little, and felt his hand come to my side—I took my coat tail up, and the other made all possible movement to move my hand, and one knocked my head once or twice—I said, "Will you be quiet if you please? I pray you leave me alone—I don't want to play with you"—they laughed, and said many disagreeable words, and squeezed my legs—I complained many times, but it was useless—they did not understand—during that time we had passed one gate, where the carriage paid the duty—they stopped at that time, and then went on again—I called the carter to stop the cart—he said nothing—he smoked his pipe, and I knocked him—he was sleepy all the night—he says, "That is very bad; you make very bad manners with that gentlemen"—then I get over the cart to go and get my portmanteau—he would not let me have it—I said, "You must let me have it"—I cannot tell the precise time when I lost my skewers—it was about one o'clock in the morning—the two prisoners were by me when I lost them—they did not push me before they left—I suppose they came to London—they stopped till I got down, but I stopped about half-road—I got my hat and port
manteau, and went to find the policeman—Stone's hand was on any pocket to get my watch out, but the skewers taken before that—I was sensible they were taken from me—Stone took them, I am certain—when they were out I was much more comfortable—I was not so squeezed—the other prisoner knocked my head to give him facility—I was not knocked at all before the skewers were taken—I was squeezed before I felt them go.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How many persons where in this cart or wagon? A. About nine or ten—I am sure of the number—they were all playing, and asking me to sing—I saw these men searched—the skewers were not found—I saw two men run away these the wagon.

Ward. There were three man sky-larking with him, and they knocked his hat into the road—he got out to get his hat, and then two man got out, and said they would walk—one of them pulled out some skewers, and I said, "Let me look at one of them"—said, "The police
man and three men are coming, "and then he got out and ran away; and when they came and took us, this man and I were both sitting together, and knew nothing about it—there was a person, of the name of Halliday, said he saw the Jews take the things out of the man's pocket.

GEORGE WOODS (police-constable V 112.) I took the prisoners into cus
tody

on Clapham Common—it was then a quarter before four o'clock in the morning—Ward was down, Stone was in the wagon—I charged them with robbing the prosecutor of three silver skewers—I found nothing on Ward but a knife, and nothing on the other but some money, that was given up.

Cross-examined Q. Were you told of three men that ran away from the wagon? A. I heard there were two—I did not try to pursue them—my brother constable did, but he did not catch them—he did not bring any man back—I saw from seven to eight person in the wagon.

JAMES HALLIDAY . I was in this wagon—I saw the prosecutor and the two prisoners there, and several others, but they are not present—I re
collect three men getting out of the front of the van—they kept putting my hat over my eyes, and the prosecutor's too—there was another young man sitting with the prisoner—I saw them do nothing, barring having three silver skewers in their hands, passing them from one to another—I turned my back to them, and was afraid to them, and was afraid to turn round, as I was threatened to have my head punched—the one that kept hitting me over my head got out first, and two others after him—the prosecutor's hat was knocked off, and I called to the wagoner to stop—he stopped and gave it him, and he got out; and then one of them put his hand round him, and he a kind of black book in his hand; and after that I saw the skewers handing about—the two prisoners had them in their hands—I do not know what became of them—the officer came up in an hour, I should think—the prosecutor got out, and went a different road, and then I saw the skewers—I expected the man had been robbed of them—I would not go away; and then the officer came up and the prosecutor, and said that he had been robbed of three sil
ver skewers.

GEORGE WOODS
re-examined. Q. What money did you find on either of the prisoners? A. I found 18d. and a four-penny piece on Stone, and on the other two knives and a box, but no money.

MR. PHILLIPS to JAMES HALLIDAY. Q. How many men ran away from the wagon? A. There—it was one of the three I saw with a black book, and taking something from the prosecutor—I do not know whether every body in the van might have seen the skewers—I had my back turned to them—the three fellows ran off—they were not pursued by the prosecutor and the policeman—I sent them after them—I do not knew how many person there were in the wagon—I should think twelve.
COURT. Q. How long before you got to Clapham Common did you see the skewers? A. Between two and three o'clock—I cannot tell the name of the place.
Ward. This man said he saw the man take them from the gentleman, and Stone said, "Let me look," and he did, and said, "Here comes the man and the officer," and then these three men got out.

Witness. I saw the man that ran away had something black in his hand, after that I saw the skewers handed about—I said I saw the man have his arms round the prosecutor—he had something black is his hand.
JURY. Q. Did you see them in any body's hands, but the prisoners? A. No—that was before those men ran away.
MR. PHILLIPS to JEAN BAPTISTE ALARY. Q. Were these skewers in paper? A. I had a leather memorandum book which I lost.
COURT. Q. Was that in the same pocket as you last your skewers from? A. No—it was some before that I lost the skewers—the
prisoner Ward had pushed me after my skewers were gone, but not before I they both squeezed me very much—they were silver skewers, about seven inches long.
Ward. It was dark when the three men knocking his hat off—I never laid my hand on him—there were fifteen or twenty men is front, and we all sat on one another's lap—I could not keep my seat.
Stone. Halliday, at the time I had the skewer in my hand, asked me to let him look at it—I said I could not.
JAMES HALLIDAY . I did not mention a word to him—I sat quite at the head of the wagon—I had no conversation with any one, except the one who offered to punch my head.
COURT. Q. Did you understand to what place the prisoner were to go by the wagon? A. I did not.
Ward. I have driven my father's wagon three or four years—the three man were Jews—I thought they were selling them about the country.
NOT GUILTY .

1627.
ELIZA BAILEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of May, 1 shift, value 1s.; 1 napkin, value 6d.; 1 towel, value 6d.; 1 saucer value 3d.; 1 1/2 ounce weight of tobacco, value 6d.; and 1 ounces weight of stone-blue, value 2d.; the goods of
John Edward Owen Sheet, her master.

JOHN EDWARD OWEN SHAW . I live in James's-street, Westminster-road. The prisoner came into our service to nurse my wife on the 4th of May, and remained until the 16th, when, in consequence of suspicion, I sent for a policeman who searched her box in my presence—it was a kind of bend-box—she handed it to him to search—he found in it a napkin, a china saucer, two packages of tobacco, and stone-blue, which were articles I sold in my shop—I afterwards went to Eaton-street, Lambeth, and found a shift belonging to my wife, and a towel—I know the towel to he mine—the prisoner said at the station-house, that she lodged at No.18, Eaton-street, and that was where we found things—her husband searched the drawer there, and produced them.

Prisoner. The napkin is mine, I have it four years—I know nothing of the saucer. Witness. I can swear to the napkin by the name of "Rinfold" being on it—it is nearly erased—we have seen them about for years with this mark on them—I bought them of a person in the King's Bench three or four years' ago—they were pawned at Fleming's, in Fleet-market, and I took them out—the prisoner went home once during the time she was in our service, and could have taken things to her lodging—I found several packages of mine lying about her room, but the things that had been in them were gone.

Prisoner. I did not know the shift was hers—I took it home by mis
take, thinking it was one of my own.

JAMES CUDDY (police-constable L 20.) I was sent for on the 16th of May, and the prosecutor charged the prisoner with stealing, a shift—I asked her if she had a box—she said, had a bit of a cap-box up-stairs—I looked her up—Mr. Shaw drew her box from under the bed, and in it I found the saucer, napkin, packages of tobacco, and stone-blue—she gave her address, "No. 18, Eaton-street, New-cut"—we went there—the land
lady said the prisoner husband was out—she sent for him—he came, and
I told him what I wanted—I went into the room, and in searching a chest of drawers, I found this shift and towel.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 25—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

1628.
MARY HAGGERTY was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of April, 1 bonnet, value 1s.; and 1 shawl, value 1s.; the goods
Mary Ann Lee, in the dwelling-house of
Eliza Thompson; and that she afterwards did burglariously break out of the said dwelling-house.

MARY ANN LEE . I am servant to Miss Eliza Thompson, who lives in William-street, Waterloo-road. I do not know the parish—house only keeps one servant—I have seen the prisoner as servant at No. 1, but she is no acquaintance of mine—she came to mistress's house on the 25th of April, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening—mistress was out—she knocked at the door, and asked if there was a servant wanted—I said, "Yes," and asked her to come in and wait till mistress came in—(I was going to leave—she sat down, and I fell asleep about nine o'clock)—mistress did not come in till twelve o'clock—I awoke between ten and eleven o'clock and she was then gone—when I fell asleep we were both in the parlourshe was sitting in a chair—I did not miss my bonnet and shawl till next morning—they had hung behind the kitchen door, down stairs—there was nobody in the house besides me and the prisoner—when I went to sleep, the street-door was shut and latched, but not bolted—it was on the when I awoke.

Prisoner. Q. When I went to the house she was doors from her own house—did not I wash up plates and dishes for you, anti sew the skirt of a gown on to a body? Witness. A. It is false—the bonnet and shawl were in the house—I had seen them recently before—these are them

JOHN COLLISON . I am a policeman. On the 26th of April, Lee came to the station-house, and gave information of losing property of her own—I found the prisoner in Tower-street, Waterloo-road, on the 11th of May, and found the bonnet on her head—I was looking for her nearly three weeks—I received the shawl from a man who is not here—the mis
tress would prosecute, and the Magistrate bound the servant over.

GUILTY of stealing only. Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1629.
HENRY GREENWELL was indicted
for that he, on the 28th of April, in and upon
James East, Unlawfully, maliciously, and felon
iously, did make an assault, and did stab and cur him on the left side of his body, with intent to kill and murder him.—2nd COUNT, stating is to be with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

JAMES EAST . On the morning of the 28th of April, I was in Morgan's-lane, Bermondsey street—I was employed, with others, in emptying a privy—I was coming out of the house, and heard the ladder thrown from the cart—I put my bucket down in the house and ran out—I saw five men near the cart, dressed in sailor's clothes—we asked them they did that for—they said, because they liked it and they would do it again if they liked—the prisoner said that—I am sure he is the man—he made a blow at me—I had not made a blow at him first—my partners ran to save, and then Hagger pitched into him, and then I and Green well began fighting—we had three rounds—he then put his hand into his pocket—I did not him take the knife out,

but I saw him open it right before me, and he stabbed me in the left side—my master came out and shoved him off me, and he ran away, hallooing "Police" several times, and Hagger followed him—this was after we had fought two rounds—I was on the ground when he opened the knife—with one knee up and the other down—he had run after me and pushed me down, and then presented the knife at me and stabbed me in the left side of my body while I was on the ground—he was on both his knees, kneeling on me with one knee on my leg, and I had one foot on the ground—the other knee was kneeling—as soon as he opened the knife he rushed it into me—my master picked me up—I told him the prisoner had stabbed me, and then he ran after him—I can swear I did not ran away after he opened the knife—I could not stir—I laid on the ground till he stabbed me.

Q. Then he never ran after you with the knife open in his hand? A. Yes, he did after the second round—he opened the knife and ran after me with it open his hand—he then knocked me down—he ran seven or eight yards before he overtook me—I went into a public-house, tied a handkerchief round my wound, and was taken to the hospital directly—I have been there seven weeks—I am not yet out of the hospital for goods.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did not you swear at the police-office that you were down on the ground, and that he drew his knife and stabbed you on the ground? A. No, 1 said when he pulled out his knife I got up and ran a few yards, and he overtook me, knocked me down. and stabled me—I did get up before my master picked me up—the prisoner had not been fighting with any body besides me—my uncle did not knock him down—I swear that the prisoner was on me on the ground, and my uncle shoved him off me—he picked me up, seeing me vary faint—after I came too I told him he had stabbed me, and he ran after him—the prisoner called out "Police" several times—he was the first person that called "Police"—I had no knife—we had been eating our supper just before—but we had the publican's knives.
NOT GUILTY .

The prisoner was afterwards
convicted on an indictment, charging the above offence as
an assault.
Confined Four Months.

1630.
JAMES WILEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of May, at Clapham, I gelding, price 5l. the property of
John Kirby.

JOHN KIRBY . I live at Balaam-hill, Streatham. In May last I had brown gelding—I sent it to be shod on Tuesday, the 31st, by my lad, to Page, the farrier, and it was then turned on Clapham Common—my lad is not here—I generally kept it in my stable, but when it is not work it goes on the Common for an hour or two, and generally comes homes of itself in the evening—it was to be turned on the common after it was shod—I did not see it again till the following Tuesday, when I saw it is a cab down at my place—it was the same horse—I gave two guineas reward for bringing it home—the value of the horse is 5l.,—I gave 10l. for it twelve or fourteen years ago.
Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Do you mean to say could get 5l. for it? A. Yes—it is an old horse—it would sell in Smithfield for 5l.—it was sent at twelve o'clock to he shod.
RICHARD THORNTON . I live at Clapham. I have known the prosecutor for years, and know his horse—I saw it on the 31st of May, about

a quarter before nine o'clock in the evening, on Clapham Common, at the top of the Common gate, by Mr. Beacket's—I saw it attempt to drink at the pool—some boys were fishing there, and they drove it away—he made another attempt—that was all saw.
Cross-examined Q. Was that near the road? A. Not a hundred yards from it.

HENRY PAGE . I am a farrier. I should the horse—it was brought to me about twelve o'clock, on the 31st by the prosecutor's lad and he took it away about three o'clock—I saw it again about a quarter before ten o'clock that evening, going along past the yard leading to my house—I live a little way down the lane, near the Bedford Arms—there was a man on it, with a halter—it was on the road towards London—I do not know who the man was—I only saw his back—I bad known the horse for twelve of fourteen years, having been in the habit of shoeing him—I am quite sure it was the same horse.

Cross-examined Q. Was it a light night? A. Not very—it was not a tall stout man on the horse—it was a slight man, I should say—I only had him in view as he passed, for a minute or two, and saw it was the prosecutor's horse—I thought there was something the matter with his other horse, and he had sent for this to fetch his cart.

ROBERT FAWCET . I am one of the toll-collectors at Kennington-gate, I know Kirby's horse perfectly well—I saw it on the evening of the 31st of May, about ten o'clock, pass through the gate towards London—there was a man riding it—I could not tell whether he had a saddle, bridle, or halter, or not—I do not know who the man was.

Cross-examined Q. He paid the toll, suppose? A. Not to me, but to my fellow-servant—there are three lamps at the toll-house—I should not think he could see his features, unless he had occasion to take notice of him—it was very light—if I liked to looked at a man's face I could see it very well—the man who took the toll was at the gate—he has never been ex
amined—I told the Magistrate that another man had received the toll from him, but that he knew no more of it than I did.

SAMUEL EKINS . I am servant to Mr. Clark in Brand-yard, Drummond-street, Euston-square—Mrs. Theobalds, his sister, lives with him. On the night of the 31st of May, between ten and eleven o'clock my mistress de
sired me to go down to let somebody in—I went found the prisoner there, on a horse—I knew him before—he had a bridle, but no saddle—I asked him what he had got, a donkey or a jackass—he said, "Why, I have got a horse"—I took him into the stable—he said, "I brought it for Charley," meaning my master; "I brought it for him to work till I get my license"—he wanted a cab license—he asked me what I thought of it—I looked at the horse's mouth, and said, "It is a very old one," and would not do him much good—that was all that passed—I put the horse in the stable for the night—Mr. Clark used him next morning in his cab—I think he used about four times—he took him our last Mon
day week, and did not came home till Tuesday afternoon, and the horse never came back—it was the same horse as Wiley brought.

Cross-examined Q. Was it not on Wednesday night all this took place? A. No; Tuesday—I have always said it was Tuesday—I was not at the police-office when the prisoner made a statement—the 31st was on a Tuesday—it was the last day of May—I know that by looking at the almanack—I looked at it a day or two after the horse was stolen—I had not seen a handbill describing as lost on the 31st of May, before I looked at

the almanack—I heard it was lost on the 31st of May, before I looked at the almanack—I said the horse was brought to me on the Tuesday before, I looked, to make sure of it—I have known the prisoner about eighteen months—he has been a cab-man, and had a license of his own, and has got one now, I believe—he lived in London Mews—I did not know where to direct the officers to find him—I cannot tell where he kept his cab—I drove for Clark—Clark did not want a cab-horse—the horse went out about four times—it was always in the night—our can works in the day as well as sight, but it was a shabby-looking horse—it did not go out every night—it was in our possession seven or eight days—it was found on Tuesday morning.

MARY THEOBALD . I am Clark's sister, and live in Brand's-yard. I have known the prisoner two years—I recollect his bringing the horse to our place on Tuesday evening, the 31st of May, between ten and eleven o'clock—he asked me to let him leave it there—he had brought it for my brother to work till he got his number—I asked Ekins to take it into the stable—I recollect it was Tuesday, the 31st of May, because my brother took it out on the 1st of June, at night—I am sure of that—I saw the horse the night it came, but did not see the colour till next morning—the prisoner asked me what I supposed he gave for it—I said, "About 5l."—he said he gave 6l. that was the night he left it.

Cross-examined Q. I suppose you did not believe him when he said he gave 6l.? A. I did give it a thought—my brother always works at night, and the man in the morning—I was not before the Magistrate when the prisoner said any thing—I was at Union-hall last Friday about it—I was the first that was called in—I did not hear the other witness say it was Tuesday—the horse went out again on Thursday night Saturday night, and Monday night—I know that, because we put it down—my brother only keeps two horses.

CHARLES CLARK . I am a cab-man. I first saw the horse on Wednes
day morning, the 1st of June in my stable, between eight and nine o'clock—I used him in my cab—on the following Monday night I had it in my cab, and drove a person to Clapham—they told me to stop against Kirby's house; and Kirby came out, claimed the horse, and gave me in charge—I gave it up after he swore to it.
Cross-examined Q. Did not Kirby tell you when he had lost his horse? A. He said he lost it that day week—I was out when it came to my stable.

RICHARD GOLDING . I am a policeman. I apprehended the prisoner on Tuesday, the 7th of June, in Euston-mews, Euston-square—I told him it was for a horse stolen from Clapham-common on the 31st of last May—he said, "I bought the horse"—I asked him. "When?—he said, "On Thursday, the 2nd of this month, and gave 3l. 10s. for it"—I asked what he did in the evening when he bought it—he said he took it to Clark's stable—I took him into custody.

Cross-examined Q. You found him where he had his cab? A. Not that I know of—he was cleaning horses—I had information from Clark, that if I went to Drummond-crescent, I should find him; but I did not find him there—I went to the stable, and saw him rubbing horses down—I said to him, "Does a man named Wiley live here?—he said, "Do you want him?"—I said, "Yes"—he put his coat on, and said, "I will go and find him"—it was what I heard at Drummond-crescent that took me to where I found the prisoner—I am sure the word "Thursday" was

mentioned in bringing him to the station-house at Clapham—nobody was present—this was on Tuesday—he said he took it to Clark's the night he bought it, and he said he bought it on Thursday—I was particular in asking him whether it was Thursday or Tuesday—he said he bought it of a man at Cow-cross, who gave his name as Jones.
Prisoner's Defence I bought the horse the horse in Cow-cross, for 3l. 10s., of a a little man, on Wednesday week last.

(Thomas Price, tea-street, Dorset-square; William Dig
gins, corn-chandler, Brewer-street, Somers-town; and William Burdett, cab-man, Grevill-street, Somers-town, gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Life.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1631.
EDWARD STRAWSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of May, 1 account-book value 1s.; 1 bag, value 3s.; and 4 pairs of shoes, value 18s.; the goods of
William Gooding, his master: and 1 account book, value 1s.; 3 pairs of shoes, value 13s. 6d.; and 1 pair of half-boots, value 6s. 6d.; the goods of
George Gooding; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

WILLIAM GOODING . I live in St. Paul's-place, Walworth-common, and am a shoemaker. The prisoner was about three weeks in my service—on Saturday morning, the 21st of May, I lost four pairs of shoes—He absented himself at the same time—I made inquiries, and found the shoes at the pawnbroker's—this is one pair of mine—this is my brother's—I lost am account-book, and my brother one, also a bag, a pair of boots.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Are you not carrying on business with your brother? A. No; he only lodges with me—I am quite sure this pair is mine, I had seen them on the Saturday morning—this pair is my workmanship, and this pair is my brother's—I do not keep a shop—only one person employs me—he would have a number of pairs of shoes manufactured by me, and they would resemble this pair—there is nothing that would distinguish them from this pair.
COURT. Q. How long before you missed these two pairs had you seen them? A. Twenty minutes before I missed them—the prisoner absented himself before breakfast.
JOSIAH WILLIAM CLARKE . I am a pawnbroker. I produce this pair of shoes claimed by the prosecutor—they were pledged by the prisoner on the 21st of May, for 1s. 6d—I cannot tell what time of the day.
Cross-examined Q. Are you quite sure of his person? A. Yes.

ROBERT COX . I am a pawnbroker, living with Mr. Farmer, in Black
friars-road. This and the other pair were brought by the prisoner about twenty minutes past nine o'clock on the morning of the 21st of May—he said they were for his brother, George Gooding, whose name is in them.
JOHN LYONS (police-constable L 161.) I took the prisoner, and found these two books and a riding belt on him.

WILLIAM GOODING
re-examined This book is mine, the other is my brother's—this is the book in which my employer puts what I take.
JAMES SYMONS (police-constable P 17) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from the Clerk of the peace, at Newington (read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 14—
Transported for Seven Years.

p.hi: Sixth Jury before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1632.
GEORGE SMITH was indicted
for misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Fifth Jury before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1633.
ROBERT COLE was indicted
for embezzlement to which he pleaded.

GUILTY .. Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

1634.
ROBERT HART was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, JULY 4, 1836.
